cluster_relations.rel_desc: The movement inspired people globally to oppose injustice.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: after and following the U.S. civil rights movement era

remarks: Relation name emphasizes the target of the inspired action (opposing injustice).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The human spirit is portrayed as having the power to overcome oppression.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: in struggles for social and political progress

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The human spirit is described as having the power to create a better world.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject inspires or motivates others to actively oppose the object (typically an injustice or oppressive condition).
args.justification: The description and hints show a causal motivational link where the movement inspires people to oppose injustice; a predicate centered on inspiring opposition best captures this reusable semantics.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject has the power or capacity to overcome, defeat, or prevail over the object (typically an oppressive or unjust condition).
args.justification: The instance explicitly frames the human spirit as having power to overcome oppression; a general predicate 'overcomes' fits this causal, success-against-adversity relation and is reusable for similar cases.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject plays a causal or enabling role in bringing about or creating the object (often an envisioned improved social state).
args.justification: The relation describes the human spirit as having the power to create a better world; modeling this as contributing to the creation of the object captures the causal, constructive role without over-specifying context.

All three relations express how abstract social agents or forces (movements, human spirit) causally influence social conditions or outcomes (opposition to injustice, overcoming oppression, creating a better world); grouping them under a common class for causal relations in social change contexts is appropriate.

Each predicate encodes a causal or enabling effect from subject to object (inspiring opposition, overcoming oppression, contributing to creation of a better world), so they all fall naturally under a broad causality group.
